On this week’s If Then, Slate’s April Glaser and Will Oremus dissect the latest fallout from the Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal, wherein the profile data of more than 50 million Facebook users was obtained and allegedly used by Donald Trump’s online voter-targeting firm.
Finally, a tech story that has gotten less attention than it probably deserves: a change in the law that governs whether websites are liable for what their users say.
They’ll also discuss the death of a pedestrian in Arizona at the hands of an Uber self-driving car, and what that means for the future of autonomous vehicles.
Will and April are joined by David Carroll, a professor at Parsons School of Design at the New School, who focuses on political campaigns and data targeting.
The hosts go deep into some of the subplots of that scandal and what it means for Facebook, elections, and your privacy.
If Then is presented by Slate and Future Tense, a collaboration among Arizona State University, New America, and Slate.
